values.title: Testing Benford's Law
values.description: An experiment to test Benford's Law against large, publicly available datasets.
values.author: Jason Long (@jasonlong), Bryce Thornton (@brycethornton) and Denis Nikolas (tg - @nikovonlas)
values.imagine: Imagine a large dataset, say something like a list of every country and its population.
values.explain: Chances are, the leading digit will be a 1 more often than a 2. And 2s would probably occur more often than 3s, and so on.
values.benford-law: This odd phenomenon is Benford's Law. If a set of values were truly random, each leading digit would appear about 11% of the time, but Benford's Law predicts a logarithmic distribution. It occurs so regularly that it is even used in fraudulent accounting detection.
values.wiki: See the Wikipedia article for a more thorough discussion.
values.simple-experiment: This is a simple experiment to see how many large, publicly accessible datasets satisfy Benford’s Law.
values.github: This site is on GitHub. Please help out by forking the project and adding more datasets or translate project.
